tx1TEaZKHQkFvuze6J5SfA.text: Newly opened in August 2013, Pizza Pilgrims Pizzeria is located on Dean Street in the heart of Soho. While the joice of location, opposite Pizza Express and just a few doors down from Soho Joe, is brave, Pizza Pilgrims already built up some fans with their pizza van, and if I have to choose between Pizza Express and Pizza Pilgrims, I do not have to think too long about where to go. When I got there, the downstairs area was busy, so I was offered a place upstairs. I reckon the atmosphere downstairs is a bit different, but it's fine upstairs, too. I was handed a menu immediately but after I was stupid enough to pass it over to my neighbours who asked me for it, I was overlooked when it came to ordering. Once this issue was fixed, the service was very friendly and attentive.I opted for the pizza Napoli Salami and also ordered a white wine. I must admit that I am not the biggest fan of their white wine on tap. It tastes ok, but that is about it for me. Whereas the pizza is as delicious as you expect if you ever bought a pizza from their van. Due to the lack of a pepper mill on my table, I could not spice it up a little bit, but really, it did not need spicing up anyway. It tasted great as it was. The pizza was not huge, but definitely big enough for me.After I finished my pizza, I looked through the desserts. Ice cream from Gelupo is undeniably a tempting option, but if you could have a Nutella pizza ring, why would you choose anything else?! If you ever went camping when you were young, you probably know campfire bread or stick bread or whatever you called it back it the days. The nutella ring tastes exactly like that, it is a simple culinary delight.Despite the abundance of Italian restaurants in the area, Pizza Pilgrims Pizzeria is a great addition and a place you should check out if you like a good pizza, because they do one of the best pizzas in London!

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom

l04dQdKNRRxsHUv2Lai20w.text: I used to think I knew the best place to go for pizza in London, but then I came to pizza pilgrims and my world was turned upside down! Fantastic. I love that it is opposite a pizza express. Why would anyone go to an overpacked average chain when this place exists next door??Pleasantly surprised to find many more tables downstairs in addition to the street level stools, we were welcomed in for lunch just before the crowds arrived. The pizza was superb, with quality ingredients, nice thin base and cooked for just the right amount of time (I.e not too long!). We had the calzone and a margherita, both excellent. You are looking at between £7 and £11 for a pizza, so pretty good for Soho and the quality. If you like pizza, this place is a must!Can't wait to return!

AiZi1bsaCgW86N3nkptPPQ.text: Great pizza dough, funky decor and a brilliant place for a party of friends to hang out. There are lots to choose from, from their menu. The portion sizes are also pretty generous. It definitely is the place to go for pizza and it makes a change from dining out at the other standard chains.

zJZHuL0aXfAbyLozeRwZKw.text: Meh. Could have done without. Service was good.. Crust was light and flavorful but mushroom truffle wasn't that fantastic unfortunately

5kb3Xuu-7HBqzjJKVDQf6A.text: Great pizza and starter. Friendly and quick service and a good beer! Have been wanting to check this place out since their van days and wasn't disappointed!

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. The garlic and rosemary flatbread. More than enough for two and delicious.

scTZmU9TfKd50excAobMjg.text: Generally really good pizzas, nice vibe downstairs and great value for money. Always end up doing work leaving lunches here, but no complaints.

w2dMjNmNspVhi7zqKuMvsw.text: Relaxed vibe, friendly staff, cheap wine: ideal. The spicy pork sausage pizza was delicious and the burrata felt like a religious experience, oozing cream and goodness. At £37 for two including Prosecco, we'll be back soon!

8AMFUC1hJ3-xZ7KQLJJWkg.text: Really good pizzas in traditional stone baked style. Great selection. Atmosphere is fairly casual an this location specifically is quite small/crowded so best to visit one of the other locations.

1F71w0UxiKxqYTMvD-9MnA.text: The best Italian pizza I have ever eaten in London. Cheap and good . Nice environment as well

jFw1CgLPhbeyebGAyaZV3g.text: I went here a couple of weeks after getting back from Italy and it's true, this is the closest I've come to getting a proper Napoli style pizza. really authentic!!! a definite must in your in the area and want a casual dining experience.

tzPeFrmHfI34iHMY9oM57Q.text: I just wanted a pizza snack so stopped by Pizza Pilgrims for a cheeky margherita. For £6.50 it was amazing! And it only took about 3 minutes to come out even though the place was busy. I definitely want to work my way through the menu.

_0PUOlwIjMZUvb5hyAk8mw.text: Pizza was tasty but the toppings were way too stingy.  The dough was also too soggy for my tastes.  It was wet and sloppy.

Ft-sMYclQcX3pWPMa17R5g.text: Quite possibly the best pizza I've had in London. The wait on a Friday night was about 40 minutes but the food was worth it and the staff were lovely. When it comes to deserts or as Pizza Pilgrims put it, 'after pizza', Nutella pizza ring is quite special. It's a shame I was so full I couldn't finish it.

dmVg30ILRi_IraqVR9RzMA.text: Very good pizza. Quite juicy. Decent value. The beer selection here is embarrassingly poor, though. If I was reviewing on the 'za alone it would get four stars, but this is a restaurant and they should have more than one crappy Italian macro lager.

d2tO-Dw8_ThWEjE7OPXRYw.text: Amazing pizza. Maybe not the best one I've had, but it comes pretty damn close and it should be tried at least once in your life. Just the look of it is amazing, the crust has got that homemade look that makes you want to tear it apart just because it would feel good to do it. That should really say it all and I'm sure I just convinced everyone to eat there now.

3HjPINeAXg3hgbaTuPZjHw.text: Such good pizza! Italian style with fresh mozerella and amazing thin crust - pizzas are pretty small, a little more than enough for an individual. The place looks like it only has takeout when you first walk in but there is a lot of seating downstairs. Staff was really friendly,service was very fast, and prices were reasonable.

wiO7MeTJKl4ieJC85Wo-cQ.text: Great Pizza! Pretty sure its right next to a pizza express; if you choose that over PP you have made the biggest mistake of your life. Also try their nutella and ricotta dessert pizza it is delicious!

sAeknRCSYJ4Np0WzADz7tQ.text: Great pizza and great service with a smile. Serve the best pizza in Soho as well

-HpGX-XLYs2khT3kyBvF1w.text: To be quite honest, I'm not entirely sure what all the fuss is about surrounding Pizza Pilgrims! To me, the pizza was just "okay". The crust was quite doughy and the cheese a bit rubbery. The restaurant itself is usually overcrowded, with terrible acoustics in the basement, so you can barely hear what your dinner company is saying. I do have to say that the staff was quite friendly, which is always appreciated! I'm never one to complain about much, but the hubbub surrounding Pizza Pilgrims left me disappointed when I went and experienced it myself! Feels like one of those places that you're supposed to say you like just because everyone else says they like it (though no one actually likes it themselves). Do I recommend this place? Meh. Save your money and go to Pizza Express. Same quality.

_vPPvd8Y3fwXRInvgXk98A.text: Good atmosphere and great pizza. Classic Italian type pizza.

M4-l0s2cq207xTvD0NnXog.text: This place is worth a visit and they have a great story.I went for the 'Nduja' which was good, cooked right - still soft and service was efficient. I would say it could be better if there were more meat toppings to choose from (my opinion).Overall - worth a visit, the sohocellos are also worth a try!

oHy25KP9yi687LoThMwgDw.text: I think the next time I'll come here I will probably give it 5 stars.This is just a perfect italian pizza place. Small, cozy, with the pizza guy working in front of people, and a big wooden oven.Small selection of pizzas (I think 6), a couple of desserts and beer. That's it, that's what I want, that's what I need from a pizza place!so let's go strarght to the main topic: the pizza!Now, first time I try a pizza spot equal margherita with bufala, BUT not here. Unfortunately I saw 'nduja, and whenever I see that magic word my brain starts to do backflips (yes, inside the cranium). So here we go, margherita with 'nduja & bufala!Now, the pizza is neapolitan style: that means soft, high, not very large, in one word: delicious. That's the only adjective. Tomato, mozzarella, perfect, just perfect, the cheese is not that melted (which is good, I don't want a layer of cheese like a cover, it's mozzarella not a quilt!). The 'nduja is probably the worst part of this dish, not because it's bad but it's a bit under-spicy (is it even a word? well you understood what I meant).. I kind of understand that, it must be good for everybody and therefore must not bee too spicy, but still it's 'nduja, not a sweet salami!The kitchen was closed before we could order the nutella ring, therefore... the 5 stars are delayed for the next trial!

KO7RBIwy7vZpZ_KS-50ptQ.text: Really lovely restaurant with authentic Italian pizza's. Service was friendly and restaurant has ample seating downstairs. It's not super fancy but is a comfortable place to eat for a casual date. They also have wine on tap which we ordered. It was lovely to have a heavily breathed wine with our lunch. My only suggestion is that they use actual wine glasses- it would make the experience better than using water cups. I ordered the Artichoke and ricotta pizza and it was very flavorsome. My husband ordered the nduja and really enjoyed it. We will definitely be back! Fair prices for quality pizza.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Artichoke ricotta pizza (bottom) and nduja (top) with house red wine.

4oP9OF0UrCE5zf1QOfijqA.text: Some of the best pizza I've ever had. I usually like the classic margherita and prefer the normal one to the selection with buffalo mozzarella. The sauce is fresh, there's just the right amount of cheese, the basil tastes great, and the dough is delicious. (Oh, DO sprinkle on the chilli oil!)Hubby and I like visiting their Soho location and their stand at Dalston Yard Street Feast, but the staff in Soho are so friendly and helpful. They always make the experience pleasant. Really need to try the nutella ring!

tdY3F3GCiQ_j41-FwzGG8w.text: The best pizza I have had in a long time!!!! I had the one with pork and fennel sausage and broccoli and it was so bloody good I would travel back to London for it!

ZupPQrXDbVoIHoMYodz91w.text: I got the Marinara one, well presented and similar to the real italian one. I also had the fried carciofi, I wouldn't say tbey were very good but it's worth trying them . prices are good and you get the tap water as well

LWXP2b0kaxDObevy-OLz-w.text: After trying out some Pizza Pilgrims at a pop up, I was tres excited to know that they had opened in the heart of Soho.. The smell of fresh pizza with a hint of basil in the air, is one to get your tummy rumbling, but do beware not to wonder around smelling with your eyes closed as downstairs in very cramped regardless of the foosball table..The nduja - spicy sausage pizza, is true to the word spicy, however if you are expecting solid pieces of meat, ask the waiter about the pizza ingredients. However, more importantly, how do you like your pizza? A must for me is a crispy base, which this lacked entirely. The sauce adds to the messy, doughy and soggy texture. The pizzas at their pop up had the same flavour but with a crispy base and slight crunch to compliment the perfect sauce and toppings.Having a litre of prosecco to wash this down with helped, but if you are prosecco-less, and more fussy than a drunken soho straggler, ask for a crispier base at the least.

ksU0B24c59DOv2tW5c6Qeg.text: I came here with a friend on a Friday after work and I was very pleased with the experience.  The pizza was tasty and everyone there was friendly and welcoming.  I would be happy to visit again.The restaurant is deep within Soho, so there are plenty of people in the area sightseeing or milling about with drinks out on the footpath.  Pizza Pilgrims was also busy, but not so crowded that we were afraid of a long wait.  As it were, there wasn't a table immediately available, but we could put our names on a list to ensure we kept our place in line.  While we were waiting, we could order drinks and just hang out outside.I was expecting a half hour wait, but a table freed up earlier than I thought.  We went to our table downstairs holding our half-finished drinks and had a look at the menu.  We ordered a drinks top-up and couple of pizzas to share between us: the Nduja (italian spicy sausage) and the Bufala (buffalo mozzarella).  Within around 10 minutes, our pizzas arrived and we tucked in.I enjoyed the fresh tomato sauce and the cheese had a nicely firm, chewy texture.  The italian sausage had more of a "pesto" texture, in random areas on the pizza, rather than being actual slices of sausage.  You could spread it across the pizza and the spiciness was a good contrast.For our 2 drinks and a pizza each, we spent approximately £20 each, including service.

2m2jrU4u2HtpT1aWgSsbVQ.text: More at: apinchofsaltandsugar.wor…Neapolitan pizza has been all the rage in the foodie world lately.  Ever since watching 'Eat, Pray, Love' a few years back seeing Julia Roberts devour hers at the famed Italian establishment L'Antica Pizzeria da Michele, Neapolitan pizza has been one of my favourite / special meals to have - which is also why I don't have it very often since it makes each occasion that much more special.Prior to creating this blog, I had been to Franca Manca in Brixton for their famous sourdough Neapolitan styled pizzas.  Still fondly remembering the experience, I turned to Pizza Pilgrims in Soho - an establishment which started out as a humble street food van turning into a full restaurant affair from their street success.  Sandwiched in between two other pizzerias, Pizza Express and Soho Joe, Dean street surely has become a pizza battleground for the three restaurants.We ordered two pizzas- pizza Bufala and Aubergine ParmigianaThe eggplant pizza was their featured item; and it was a disappointing pizza.. scarcely dotted with eggplant (ok fine, I will call it aubergine since we are in Europe) which made this topping quite pointless as you could barely taste the 'aubergine' as it was overpowered by the stronger flavours of cheese and tomato.Unfortunately, the mozzarella pizza was not cooked as well as the eggplant as demonstrated from the extent of charring or 'leoparding' seen on the base.The mozzarella also wasn't bubbling hot, and had lost is melting consistency (it was rather gummy by the time I started eating it) suggesting perhaps the pizza was left on the counter for a bit too long after being removed from the oven.There's been longstanding debate whether Neopolitan pizza should or should not be soupy. It appears Pizza Pilgrims have adopted the soupy philosophy in the centre, But, think I prefer a much more crisper base similar to what I had at Franca Manca.Overall, I was a bit disappointed in Pizza Pilgrims.  Perhaps it has been a victim of its own success; the pizzas not achieving consistency due to the volume of demands. There's Soho Joe next door also known for pretty good Neapolitan pizzas too... maybe one to put on my wishlist

I0D_Ibg1Ka5Qs1OEUdKvYw.text: After the Yelp Event we had here I fell head over heels in love with this place!They really have some of the best pizzas here, but please don't ask me which one, I just can't decide. Bloody Mary-nara is so special, so spicy so amazing for a hangover, Nduja is delicious and a bit spicey too, the pizza with mushrooms and truffle oil is heaven on earth and all the others are also so worth a try.Friendly people working here and a great atmosphere if you sit downstairs.Unfortunately it was full when I last came here and me and my friend were sitting upstairs which is not as comfy but what don't you do for a good pizza? Love this place!

jaE5Y5CNVDv2y-0FfxK8nA.text: Hands down the best pizza in London - and it beats some Italian pizzas, too. It has the Italian's seal of approval! The mushroom pizza and even just their margheritas rock. And don't get me started on that Nutella ring.

aYJYEdf7UjeEajSEU62uCg.text: Best pizza I tried in my life!This is a very quaint and cozy small joint with excellent pizza. The service was very good and hospitable. The menu is fairly short, pizza topping combinations are simple and pizzas aren't overcrowded with too many flavors. I ordered a vegetarian pizza with aubergines, thinly sliced garlic, fresh basil, fresh milky mozzarella (usually cheese lefts me with a heavy feeling in my stomach, but this one was light) and yummy tomato sauce. The dough was baked to perfection and the rim was very soft but chewy - the best dough I ever tasted and I make a pretty good pizza myself. The ingredients complimented itself beautifully and I cannot wait to come back for more!The story of Pizza Pilgrims is a fairly interesting one too - 2 brothers who left their boring jobs, went to Italy and learned how to make pizza. I am always glad to support such artisans.

XPbsgbDDVvooW_x6DENhwQ.text: Small and rustic Neaple style pizza place. Their pizzas are top class. One of the best in London. It gets very busy during peak hours

MBt_clteNlodcON0bOkX2Q.text: My friends and I ate here on a Friday night at like, 9:45 pm.  Try getting a table anywhere in Soho without a reservation earlier than that, ugh!  We waited for over an hour, maybe even a bit more.  At long last, we got our table downstairs and tucked into our pizzas.  If you're hungry, you can easily finish one yourself.  If you're hungrier, you should be able to go to town on some extras like the delicious flatbread and marinated artichoke hearts with prosciutto and parmesan (mmmmm).  I can't remember which pizzas we had, but I remember all the ingredients were fresh and the crust was really soggy.  This is normal for Neopolitan style pizza, but I can't say I enjoy it.  Well - the crust is crisp on the perimeter, but the middle gets very soft where the hot toppings sort of melt in to the centre.  It's knife and fork pizza, so just know that going in!  And the nutella ricotta pizza ring was a great way to end the meal, if you're a total fatty - and we were.Pretty affordable prices, and once we were actually seated, service was quick!  Though it isn't my favorite kind of pizza, I'd come back again.  They have a fun late-night vibe and a lot of yummy options.

LxnAnvD0cIABQjMUSiq5Tg.text: All in all the atmosphere is easy and fun and the food was average.  The burrata with smoked tomatoes was good, the cheese and the smoked tomatoes were absolutely perfect, the arugula was an odd pairing because the spice of the arugula overpowered the delicate cheese if I put more than two little leaves on.  I ordered the pizza Napoli with black olives, capers, smoked anchovies and buffalo mozzarella the combination was delicious but the crust was a little under done for my preference.

yjFacArlKQ0W48CLTeuEAQ.text: Pizza was decent, we ordered the Nduja (spicy sausage) and the Salsiccia (fennel sausage ).  Definitely preferred the Saliccia.  I asked for mine to be extra crispy because I have an aversion to doughy pizza dough and they humored me.It's hard for me to be super excited  because I've been totally spoiled by New York pizza, but it's a solid place.  The wait was a bit long because we came during prime feeding time.  They don't take bookings under 8 people so we put our name  down on the list and grabbed beers at Toucan Bar across the street.For 4 pizzas and drinks, it all came down to 10 quid a head for 4 people, which is amazing in London.  Hard to get this price even in Chinatown.

kOqP0BNwv_6C6tGzx4hdAg.text: The atmosphere in here is nice, although the tables are super close together so you're probably going to be getting quite cosy with strangers.the guys serving were very nice & friendly - and service is SUPER quick. assuming you don't have a wait for a pizza, you could be in and out of here easily within 45 minutes.there is a small, interesting menu to choose from. my friend and i split the mushroom pizza and the margharita pizza. both were tasty, although not the best pizza i've had in London. i might have awarded it 3 stars based on the pizzas being nice, but not amazing, but i think partnered with the service, reasonable prices, location and atmosphere, they deserve 4 stars as i would be happy to recommend eating here, and i will definitely come back.we ordered a carafe of prosecco between us - we love prosecco but don't order it out often, so this was a real treat! i think it had been sitting out in the carafe however as it was quite flat and not as bubbly as prosecco normally is. i thought this was really disappointing, so maybe something to note for future :)

rSssib61hVEWpPjd4PNU_w.text: The best pizza in town!!! I love it there. Mostly you have to wait until 20-30 minutes to get a table but is definately worth it!!!

SsecUsvigaKuX-YSU4PTIA.text: I've been debating over whether or not I wanted to write a review for Pizza Pilgrims for ages because eh, but yelp keeps harassing me to do so since I actually checked in, so I guess I will!Here's why.  It should be good.  Pizza Pilgrims should be at the top of my pizza pyramid in London.  But it isn't.  And why isn't it?  Because I've had Homeslice, that's why.  And the Pilgrims, while close, just don't match up.Maybe it was the fact that only one person seemed to be the front of house AND the only waitstaff thus making service extremely spotty... although said gentleman was lovely.  Maybe it was the fact that the toppings seemed less exciting.  Maybe it was the size/price ratio.  I don't know, but I just wasn't blown away.We had two pizzas: one with sausage and wild broccoli, and the portobello mushroom and truffle.  The 'shroom and truffle was pretty tasty, but the sausage left something to be desired.  Maybe it could benefit from a little sauce other than the olive oil.The crust is pretty tasty, though... so I think the pizzas just need a bit more pizazz.  Overall, a solid option, but I don't see myself returning too often.

slFVb8VhJUEznSBk9NL4fA.text: We ordered a pizza each - Aubergine Parmagiana and the guest pizza that evening (The Pepper Pig). Along with the pizza we ordered two side dishes. Then we finished our meal sharing a Nutella and salted ricotta pizza ring. The restaurant kindly added a scoop of ice cream. This satisfy my food buddy taste buds with the pizza ring and my taste buds with ice cream. The warm pizza ring filled with melted Nutella tasted good with the cold ice cream. An excellent optional combination.The pizza at Pizza Pilgrims serves soft pizza base. Its probably not for those that like there pizza with a crispy base. However I enjoyed the texture of the pizza base!

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Aubergine Pamagiana

yDIfJFn35qMyvdogMi4OyA.text: The pizza itself was really tasty, although I wasn't really fond of the super burny taste underneath it, but that's just personal taste. The pizza was really thin while the crust was enormous and thick and even though the portions are just right for a small eater like me who was very hungry, I still didn't think it was that great... It's good if you're in the area on your own and are hankering for some good pizza though!!!

AqfthQ_tUkj3WR748QFphA.text: While everyone raves about this place, I wouldn't go as far to say it's the *best* pizza in London, but it does come pretty close.  We tried out the Kingly Courty branch on Carnaby St as we figured it would be a little easier to grab a table, thankfully despite it being around 7pm we were seated straight away. The menu has a lot of great options, ranging from plain margaritas to more creatively topped pizzas I can't begin to pronounce. They have toppings for both veggies and meat lovers, and seemed happy to make any amendments (within reason) to the toppings for you - I'm no fan of goats cheese and they made sure not to add it for me.  The pizzas are great value for money, come out of the oven piping hot with cheese so melted it turns into string when you tug the slices away.   The only thing that I felt did let it down was how sloppy it was - I'm a big 'eat pizza with your hands' kind of girl, preferring to cut it into slices, but I had to fold the slice in half to be able to eat it without all the topping sliding off onto the plate.

Jxmdtl1hEG8GF5urbhoh1w.text: This places does pizza well. Napoli style so it's not a crispy base ; like NY pizzas but softer so you can fold it or use a knife and fork. What this place excels at is the pizzas that have the tomato base sauce. It's very good and makes a hero of this ingredient. It's up there with Franco Manca for London pizzas.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom

AMhePVuXXElOC6FWJKf5Ag.text: As soon as I walked into Pizza Pilgrims, I wanted to give it five stars. I mean, it's not every place that you walk into the door and the waitstaff are having a spontaneous "Seasons of Love" sing-a-long because the song happened to get played over their sound system. I was tempted to join in. I kinda did sing it at my seat a bit, but not as loudly or awesomely as they did. Although the server did comment that I was singing along too. I mean how could you not?However, I knew that I would need to try the food before I could actually make that final decision. I ordered the special pizza (a selection of two italian meats, cheese and basil on a tomato base) and a side salad (because eating a healthy salad cancels out the pizza, right?) I also had one of the Italian beers that was on special for the month.I sat upstairs by the window because I was on my own, so I got to see everyone walking by. The venue does look small, but there is more seating downstairs. The beer was really good. Whoever chooses the beer here has a great palate. My salad arrived and it looked fantastic. A nice mix of greens, capers and cheese. It also tasted fantastic. Wow. Probably one of the best salads I've had at a restaurant. Someone put a lot of thought into it. The pizza was tasty as well. A sparse amount of toppings, but just enough. And the dough is really spongy and delicious. I really can't fault it.I totally wanted to try the Nutella ring, but i was on my own, so I couldn't order a whole one for myself. I mean my salad wouldn't cancel out that as well. And also I was really full. But I'm sure I'll be back to give it a try. It put me in a good mood for the rest of the night. I had "Seasons of Love" running through my head when I ran a few more errands before seeing the show I was planning on watching that night. Then I put the Rent soundtrack on when I got home and was getting ready for bed. All thanks to Pizza Pilgrims. Delicious, Delicious Pizza Pilgrims.

pjs30LQuWqzz8zL-ORFQ0g.text: After attending an event here I knew I had to come back to sample some more. So I popped along one Friday evening with the husband. Unfortunately the ambience doesn't quite lend itself to a romantic dinner, but we were quite happy to ignore each other and check our phones while scoffing these gorgeous pizzas anyway.Service is relaxed, but once you've ordered the food doesn't take long to arrive, as these thin and traditional pizzas require so little time in their oven. I stuck to 'plain' margarita and enjoyed every tasty mouthful.I would go back with friends, but not if I was hoping for a quiet and intimate meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Pizza margarita!

hHyBnpIS0BE1RcpPYx0J7g.text: I liked this place. It had a nice ambience, and the music was cool. The service was about a 7/10 so not perfect but still good. The prices are good, but the wait time can be quite long depending on the time of day (don't go if you have less than an hour). The pizzas itself was ok. Very fresh dough and ingredients, but my margarita pizza was a little thin and soggy near the middle of the pizza. Not horrible, but not the best either. I would be in no rush to go back here, but overall I was satisfied.

AJcjcjK-p2Vd98iK-JhFGw.text: Tasty pizza. Margherita was my choice, together with white rosemary and garlic white pizza!Good attendance in a fabulous place.

pjoua0rUcbWcdHoZFqc92w.text: Friend recommended me this place for pizza so we had couple of drinks and then came. Tables are very close so if you want privacy probably you won't feel comfortable but if you just want a really really good pizza, just come here. We had to wait 20 min, exactly that. Order less than 5 min and food came less than 10 min. Pizzas were really tastefully, you could feel all the ingredients and definetly were not dry but with the own ingredients liquid. Really enjoyed it. Beers at pub price and pizzas at a really correct price.Definitely I'll recommend it if you like pizza!

_j7yiwHBskcgXGq3IeuC-w.text: This pizza is one of my favorites in London. There's usually a queue, but it's often worth it. They are fire cooked pizzas with tomato sauce that makes my mouth smile. I highly recommend this spot to any pizza lover (and who doesn't love pizza).

sBys6uDQUQ5hnQkyOSIk3w.text: Living in London for almost five years as an expat from NYC, I've gradually gotten happier and happier with the food. But pizza, dear pizza, was always London's downfall. I've found myself settling on Papa John's (and worse!) and had almost convinced myself it was close to the real deal (see: Firezza review). But alas, one trip home and I was launched back into reality and scolding my tastebuds for ever settling.And then there was Pizza Pilgrims - when it started as a food truck, I had my first bite and that desire to write off carbs for the summer was abandoned.  Now, perfectly located on Dean Street (and literally a hop away from Soho Theatre if you're looking for some basement comedy!), this is always one of my first choices for a meet up with friends if we're all central.Numerous trips to Naples and NYC later, I find that I can't wait to get back to London for a pie to myself.  The staple menu items are always a delight, but you can never go wrong with the featured pie.  As a lover of all tomato based pizzas, I just recently decided to take the plunge and have the mushroom and truffle instead...and may now be a convert. That being said, the staff is always super accommodating and during that particular switch, they offered to bring me a glass of red sauce on the side for dipping (just in case! - I'm happy to report that the sauce alone is fresh and delicious!).  Grab an aperol spritz to accompany your pizza and if you're feeling sassy try some of their new limencello to finish.  Though they don't take reservations, I have never had too long a wait for a table - and as mentioned earlier this is the perfect place to stop before an evening comedy show!

wsY6Mz6eOj8tm_x6m9SlAA.text: LOVE Pizza Pilgrims - it's the only place I go to when I'm craving pizza now! I spent nearly 2 years living in Italy and whilst no English pizza can really compare - Pizza Pilgrim is my top London place for delicious fresh tasting pizza with a thin enough but doughy enough base. I've had so many different types of pizza here - I love that they have a guest pizza so I can always have something different - I've yet to ever try dessert here because I'm always so full by the end of it!Prices are really affordable and it's decor downstairs is cute and clean. In the summer they even have outdoor seating - really a gem in the heart of soho.

qY9_Z3o2lOt5xjCceywSVA.text: Oh God Pizza Pilgrims is honestly one of the best pizzas I've ever eaten this side of the Atlantic (nowhere beats Grimaldi's in NYC!)Apparently this place used to be a pop up kinda pizza van thing until they decided to get their own lot and set up a restaurant. I was there a couple of weeks ago and absolutely loved it - you definitely need to try it out here if you're wanting non traditional but ridiculously tasty pizza. Lovely staff, nice cosy Italian cafe vibe if you're seated downstairs and a generally good time - definitely recommend!

lryuU5P6zvY7GEl6ReFP4g.text: 4.5 stars.Yes yes yes. Best Neapolitan pizza in London I've had so far. Good Neapolitan pizza is oddly difficult to find in the city. There are a bunch of places that offer it, but it's not up to snuff. This place is the real deal.Saturday afternoon for a party of 2, there wasn't much wait. Maybe 5-10 minutes. The place is super casual and decorated like a no frills pizza joint. But the quality of the food is fantastic.Marinara - Tomato, oregano, fresh garlic, basilMargherita - Tomato, fior di latte, parmesan, basilFirst rule of authentic Neapolitan pizza places is that they will offer a Marinara. The marinara and the margherita are the two classic Neapolitan pizzas. So many places don't have a marinara. Those are the places you should be more sceptical of (although of course some do turn out to be quite good). The marinara and margherita are both quite plain and simple pizzas, but the test of the quality of a pizza shop is in these two. The marinara in particular really allows you to taste the dough and the tomato sauce, the two most important aspects of a quality pizza. Both were hits here. The dough was right in taste and texture, the tomato sauce was a great balance of tart and sweet - almost neutral is the key. The fresh garlic, basil, and oregano were great additions. In the margherita, the fior di latte was great quality. Not rubbery in texture at all like so many other pizza places and definitely fresh.The price is amazing as well and the portion size is satisfying. I will absolutely be back.

ArnoehVCDCjmIiXLQ6FTDw.text: I loved this pizza the first time I went. I had the pizza with fennel sausage, broccoli, fior di latte cheese, parmesan and basil and it was tasty stuff! However, since having Franco manca pizza and Homeslice I would choose those over Pizza Pilgrim. I prefer the dough and the toppings are a little more generous I think. Also the second time we went we received poor service meaning one of our group didn't get his pizza until we had all finished ours, and it was plonked on the table without a word. Rude! But they didn't charge us for that pizza in the end which was better than nothing!

bcpg4CvKScQuAVBsIOrqDQ.text: The menu is split it to sections such as 'Pizza' 'With Pizza' and 'After Pizza', which gives you no illusions about what the focus is here! There were ten pizzas on the menu including a guest pizza, which changes regularly. None of the pizzas have particularly complex toppings - the Salsiccia e Friarielli, bianca base, fresh fennel sausage, wild brocolli, fior di latte, parmesan, basil & olive oil (£11) is probably as busy as it gets. Less is more at Pizza Pilgrims and the quality of simple ingredients is the key to their offering. Sides include one of my favourite salads, Panzanella (£5) and Buffalo mozzarella with oven roasted pepperonata (£6).We decided to keep it simple with a Margherita (£8) for Antonia and the Nduja (£9), which was a Margherita with topped with Nduja sausage. We also ordered a Berwick Street Market Salad (£3) on the side. Much to our delight Pizza Pilgrims have Birra Moretti on draught for £4.50 per 400ml glass, which took us straight back to our week in Tuscany last year.

0e2N7RlTQsWWk1qOtPzlFw.text: Best pizza in London. No contest. I come several times when I visit. They use actual Caputo flour and san marzano tomatoes with the proper oven. The staff is lovely and the bufala is divine.

0WRTftRmho6ANyYuDxZZvg.text: We stopped in for a quick dinner before going to see Les Miserables at the Queen's Theatre in Shaftesbury Ave. Unfortunately they were too busy to eat in, but we ordered take away and then sat outside under the heaters and ate the pizza of our laps instead.I order the Napoli Salami and it was delicious! The crust was perfect, all puffed up around the edges, the perfect level of chewy, doughy, and crunchy. And I really liked the way they shredded the salami so that you got some in every bite. Sometimes you just get four big rounds of salami and I feel like I have to really consider how I eat each slice (I know this is weird, don't think about eating the pizza, just eat it).Sitting outside on a bench was a perfectly acceptable option for us, but the wait for a table was only around 15 minutes so it's definitely not necessary if you're not in a hurry.

7A26kuj8KORQ_zacwd2Xfg.text: I've been working my way through the London pizza scene trying to figure out what's best and I swear this has got to be near the top of the list. The pizzas are delicate with an incredible crust and perfect toppings. The ambiance is casual and the staff is attentive (even by UK standards). Great selection of beers to wash down your pizza too including interesting choices from both Italy and England. Can't wait to go back.

36cO28XrmFEWLvnM3M6Kdg.text: I'm quite picky when it comes to pizza - sludgey doughy versions do nothing for me, which is why it's a joy to find a really good Pizza place in London. Pizza Pilgrims in Soho is some of the best Pizza I've had this side of Italy. Really crispy and full of flavour. Recommended.

TINi-f2_Goe2yDyT8hr31w.text: The rudest service I've dealt with in London in the past seven months. My fiancé asked if they had gluten free pizza, because she has celiacs, and she laughed and said she didn't have an allergy. Then I said her comment was rude, and she said I was an American so I wouldn't get it.She was the blonde server at the door. She claims she's been in the industry for years and is used to that request for GF pizza. Surprising she's been in the service industry for so long being such a rude, American hating, piece of crap. Embarrassing for the restaurant to have someone like that as the welcoming face to your restaurant.Maybe her British health care will help her crooked gross teeth?

Wxhs1K1XYHIj0DUcyLFQqQ.text: Fresh and tasty pizza? This is the place. I pre-order one for lunch online and paid online, then pick it up at the shop whilst watching them cook it in the pizza oven and then they slice it into quarters. By the third slice I was so happy and full that I enter into food coma. Remaining slice became next day's breakfast.Cheerful staff. Happy customer. My order was for a Smoked Napoli £8.00Margherita with smoked anchovies, black olives, capers & oregano. Delicious.PS: You can takeaway or sit in. There is also a downstairs seating area.

3DyttUtjYZU1eJcrPJA3zw.text: Occasion: this place is great for groups of two or three. Good Location:It's in the heart of Soho. Great Pizza : fresh, tasty but not the biggest variety of flavours. I was a bit stuck on which to choose...Desserts: very yummy but the salted ricotta and nutella ring was lots of dough again. Affordable: pizzas were all if not one less than £10 but compared to Franco Manca which are on average £6.75 it may be less value for money Service: excellent and made the experience very enjoyable. Ross and Paul served us well.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom

oDjR6X48IL6Fk5TNORLq4Q.text: Friend and I were walking around Soho, and we stumbled into this place on a whim.  We asked them what their most popular pizzas were, and they said they were the margherita with sausage and, for vegetarians, the eggplant.  We didn't end up going with their decision, but the ones we got were amazing.  We got the margherita with buffalo mozzarella and the mushroom and truffle oil. Each pizza was slightly under 10 pounds. It was close to the best pizza I've ever had.  The one problem I have with Neapolitan pizzas are that sometimes the crust gets burned or sometimes it's too crispy.  But this crust was nice, and the dough was nice and soft.I will miss this pizza in the US!

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Portobello truffle oil
Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Margherita bufalo

WMyEA4rz-GyHL1G6EsTyqA.text: You guys. Five stars on Yelp are rarer than an orgasm on a Tinder date, but Joseph Jesus and Mary here we go, London has found itself some FUCKING italian masterpieces. As I do, here's a disclaimer: I'm from the South of Italy, and I am therefore the ultimate authority on pizza, pasta and general manscaping practices.  This is as good as it gets, pizza-wise. BUT PLEASE NOTE: If you are one of those complete dickwads who think Pizza Hut is pizza, please fuck off my page and never go to Pilgrims. Seriously.

f5ffM241jPHO2N0U3TrtqQ.text: I'm usually faithful to Franco Manca: they do very good pizza at a very reasonable price,  have lovely staff etc etc. I thought there couldn't be any better pizza in London. But yesterday I might have cheated on them with Pizza Pilgrims and (I can't believe I'm writing that) in was even better.  The main difference for me lays mainly in the atmosphere (who can resist a well-curated pop/rock playlist?) and the dough,  which is slightly more chewy at Pizza Pilgrims and totally won me over.  Can be a bit of a hassle to get a table though,  but with the sun coming up more and more often,  I can already tell you there'll be many pizza picnics in my summer life!

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. 'Nduja Pizza at Pizza Pilgrims

TJJxVAO6hLsXeXPXxbsdTg.text: I tried the rest and this is the best. Truly great pizza place,  there's variety on the menu and room for customization. They always have a 'guest pizza' that changes frequently so there's always a reason to come back! It's not the cheapest but it's in line with London prices. Seating is downstairs, it can seem a little cramped but it has charm. I've been back to Pizza Pilgrims regularly, go and find out why.

zwP4cdovKw9VAm4-XEWb2A.text: I've had this bookmarked on Yelp and is one of the few pizza establishments I have wanted to try.   As we were in the area we decided to go there after work.  We were seated very promptly and the waiter took our order promptly however the service after this fell away as we were ignored for a fair while after we had received our food and also I had to remind them that they had not given us the olives we had ordered.Now I have dealt with the minor negative onto the positives.  The food here is amazing.  The pizza is SOO good.  I really liked the spicy sausage pizza as well as the guest pizza of the month we ordered.  The crust is quite filling whereas the actual pizza is thinner thus allowing you to appreciate the toppings.  The menu offers a few options but I can imagine all of them are quite good, would like to try different pizzas.I liked how they served wine, cocktails and water all in the same glasses offering a no nonsense approach.  You are there for the food and not the other distractions.  We also shared a dessert with a Nutella filled dough ring which was fantastic, one suggestion I would say is to have it with ice cream as I would imagine they would go well together however we were so full I don't think we could of handled both!The cocktails on offer were nice and overall the bill was not as bad as I expected for what we ordered.  Would recommend pizza pilgrims for sure!

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Espresso martini - frothy
Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Spicy sausage pizza
Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Dessert

uWPVDFpM87qmjzd0V__MFQ.text: Whoever thought of this Nutella ring is absolute genius! The dough is thin, crispy and only slightly doughy.  Could have more Nutella filling but it is so warmingly satisfying in the cold streets of London. A late night snack perfect to fill the smooth tooth.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Nutella ring
Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom

mzoFzTFzEueygkoOzGvI8w.text: Having seen the founders on the Food Network channel demonstrating various ways of topping a pizza, I was keen to try one of theirs. I ordered the Marinara and I wasn't disappointed! It was fresh, simple but delicious. I haven't had time to go back but I'm looking forward to my next visit. I spent the summer in Abruzzo, Italy and had a local pizza bianca topped with potatoes and fresh rosemary, could you please add that to your menu?

Ma8_EYqXuxslcnzd3w9vWw.text: Pizza Pilgrims is a little gem on Dean Street. Not far from tourists on Oxford Street, yet always packed with locals. I agree: Their pizzas are really good. Not the best, but good.The dough is based on sourdough. I like these types, so I find Pizza Pilgrims to be good. Finally the Nduja sausage was really good. Spicy, creamy and spot on. I missed a little more flavor in the pizza - and it became a little boring after a while. With that said, the pizzas here are a bargain.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom

aaeRGVMqLZQHV2fBDWn9yw.text: My husband and I are Napoli pizza fanatics. We've tried so many places - including the infamous Da Michele's. This place is not that (but no where is) but this was in the A+ category as far as our global Napoli pizza trying goes. We ate pizza 3 times in 2 days here. Seriously - don't second guess and try the others (we did do one other one) - this is the place to go if you're in London looking for Napoli pizza. The soho location was also the most fun to visit if you're in the area!

TnCQM2wFpRRpLx4ZpYqolg.text: NYC better watch its back. The Pizza Pilgrims could cross the pond and lay serious waste to any pizza joint it comes across there. First off, I guess word hasn't gotten out too much about how good this place is, or London is just not as into pizza as it should be since I visited twice and didn't have to wait longer than 5 minutes for a table. A pie this good stateside would have a line half-a-mile long out the front door. The dough is divine, the sauce is savory and the ingredients are incredible. (See what I did there?) I ordered the Salami, which was basically a Margherita Pizza with thinly sliced salami and it was such a convincing piece of pizza artistry that on my second visit (THE NEXT DAY!!!) I had it again. Not a single bite was spared on either pilgrimage. The pizzas came out of the oven minutes after ordering them and for incredibly reasonable prices given how damn tasty they are. The ambiance was chill/hispter and I loved it. There's pretty much nothing I would change about this place if given the chance. One the second visit I even sprung for the much fabled nutella roll-thing-a-ma-bob. It was as good as they say it is, though they give you enough to split with 4-5 people so there was no way me and the wife could finish that thing.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Yumazing. NYC aint got nothing on these dudes.

vI64iwarJ_Wz6fikovfWLA.text: The pizza was like a home made Italian village pizza. I had a pizza with mushroom and my friend had one with aubergine. The aubergine pizza has lots of thin sliced garlic, we liked it a lot.The staff is friendly but it is difficult to order sth, you can't catch their eyes unless they want you to :) The restaurant is very warm and smells like home, price is good too. I would highly recommend this place.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. mushroom pizza

LlN12uUWhMKWf5xxGKFXow.text: Great pizza, but skip the dessert!I came here as a group of 10 for a co-workers birthday. We were seated downstairs in a separate room off the main restaurant. The restaurant sounded quite loud so it was nice to be a little more secluded away from the main dining area.I ordered the 'aubergine parmigiana'. The dough was soft and squidgy, whilst still being thin-crust. I really enjoyed the fluffy consistency of it- I preferred it to the super thin and crispy base that you often find at London pizza restaurants. The toppings were also really tasty and flavourful. The one thing I might criticize is that the pizza was a little oily in the middle. The servers brought us chilli oil and chilli flakes to accompany the pizza.To finish, I had the espresso with nutella, which was quite tasty.. but then again anything with nutella is gonna be good.. right?! Other's in the group had the affogato. The ice-cream came in a tub making it a little difficult for them to pour the espresso on top! I tried some of the nutella and salted ricotta pizza ring. I have to say I was a bit disappointed- there was no where near enough filling and where the nutella had been baked it had become a bit dry. Boo.Overall we had a really enjoyable meal, with very attentive service. It was also very affordable for Soho, at about £18 per head for dinner, drinks and dessert. Our limit on the table was 2 hours, but as the service was so good, we finished with time to spare. I will definitely be back- but just for the pizza!Oh and this place was packed on a weekday evening! So be prepared to wait. Alternatively, if you are a group of 8 or more like we were, you can pre-book the separate room downstairs!

5cq_mqRZZB4VPVWvM3owig.text: Delicious pizza. Tried the calzone witch I'm not a huge fan of in general however this was delicious. Followed up with affogato very yummy. Make sure to leave room for deserts. We also tried the chocolate pizza. Everything was delicious and the service was great. Forgot to take pictures hopefully next time I'll remember.

qy3u4eR3MnouVhJBC3HUyw.text: On our first night in London we had aimed to go to a certain restaurant but on finding on getting there that it was about to close we wandered around until hunger drew us into this restaurant.  Nothing special is how I would describe it .  The ambience is good, the staff nice enough, they have music pumping out of a sound system downstairs and the pizza are of pretty good quality.  Service from ordering to food on table did not take long and the price for here not too bad.  Only negatives....the tables are far too close together so much so that after finishing we could have given you a word for word run down on the daily life, personalities etc of the four people sitting on the next table!!!!  This I hate.  Restaurants need to learn to give customers more space and thus more privacy. Because of this I dropped a star.  Good point is location...in Soho and  not far from where a lot is going on especially at night time.  Overall I think a good place for something nice and quick if you are on a night out...but definitely not for a romantic evening.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom

mRl6zP1ZDA9iTTCBMtjJlw.text: The place is great, but the food, oh God.The ingredients are fresh and professionally selected. The pizzas are carefully made and almost taste like the Italian ones. I ordered Capricciosa since it is my favourite type and the taste was unreal. I can't express the joy of tasting so much flavours in my mouth.Creamy, melted mozzarella cheese, fresh tomatoes, delicious baked ham, mushrooms and condiments.That pizza has me still thinking about her.I probably shouldn't write reviews when I'm hungry.

vPQL1JZEi8ND6s3Tb0O04Q.text: The hype, oh yeah, it's totally real! The pizza's in this place are the bee's freakin' knees. True Neapolitan in style, with big thick crusts, but soft and slightly doughy. A real good smokiness to the pizza and ever so slightly charred. The topping are just class, the tomatoes rich and bursting with flavour, not sweet, perfectly seasoned, so simple and fresh and it all tastes so darn good!!!  The mozzarella was also really delicious and fresh and the pizza wasn't completely smothered in the stuff, happy days :)Service, meh, not the best if I'm honest. I was waiting around 15-20 minutes for my pizza, which, given how busy the place was, was fine by me. However, I didn't get the beer I ordered until AFTER my pizza arrived, I was gasping for a drink by that point, so minus a wee half brownie point there.The other half brownie point disappears for again, pretty crappy service, this time for mega slow payment of the bill. It took well over 10mins to pay for one pizza and a beer (and I was sitting next to the till). Countless staff walked past and chose to ignore my money which I had placed invitingly at the end of the table. Once my change did come back I noticed they had somehow paid the wrong bill, doh! Not sure if this is normal, but clearly these guys were having a bit of a 'mare that night.Not to worry, I certainly didn't go for the fine silver service experience. What I was hoping for was a top notch, authentic pizza, and on that front they totally delivered.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Pizza Nduja. Oh yeah baby!

UKQkGNTO5kKV3Oqorav4rg.text: How they manage to burn the pizza base while at the same time creating soggy limp pizza defies the laws of chemistry. Horrible pizza- give it a miss

qWbSGx90QZLzDsImKFhBdQ.text: I've found orgasms. They are round and cheese flavoured!I was told about this little gem by the guys at SORTEDfood. (Watch them on YouTube if you're a foodie with a sense of humour)Every pizza looks like it could take you to foodie heaven & I've been told that they do. Well to me it lead to a foodgasm. And I didn't feel dirty or cheap as it cost under a tenner. A tenner for a a filling, delicious round cheesy orgasm. The staff were friendly and happy that I was friendly too. I have to be I'm Northern. I may look like a bulldog chewing a wasp, but it's nice to see my friendliness reciprocated.Go here if you're hungry & on Oxford Street or exploring Soho.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom

6l6kbgnifsX19c7moycC9Q.text: I ordered a margarita pizza to go and it was SO good! The crust is perfectly thin and crispy and the cheese to sauce ratio is spot on. I can't wait to try other pizza's!

J33Zaf_mt_UQtKA6W5QfTA.text: AH-MAZING pizza. Oh my god this restaurant just smells good alone. I came here on a Sunday evening in April and sat outside. It was a gorgeous day! I ordered margherita pizza with mushrooms and my friend ordered their calzone. The pizzas came out unbelievably fast! They were SO good. The dough is incredible. It's soft but has a slightly salty taste to it. The sauce and cheese was so good too. My friend's calzone was incredible as well. It had cheese and sauce on it but was stuffed with sausage and more fillings! This place has the best pizza in London!

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Margherita pizza with mushroom

pZQGksBV5oooqaVa2_xMZA.text: Very inviting from the street and I wish we could have sat upstairs, but we got directed downstairs. The service was quick and to the point. The pizza we ordered was good (if you're not super hungry a single pizza could feed 2). The flavors we're all there, the sauce is bright and tasty, the cheese is good. I liked the taste of the crust, but the style of pizza makes this pizza soggy. It's not crisp at all. It's a chewy dough. While some may like this, it's personally not my favorite. By the time the pizza makes it to your table the entire center of the pizza has turned to wet bread.

LyvesTg5LdKUAoImfoH95A.text: Pros: Delicious Italian style pizza. Outdoor seating area with plenty of heat lamps, so you can stay warm.Cons: The pesto dipping sauce was sadly, awful. It tasted sour. The staff seems quite flustered, they forgot our drinks and it took quite a while to get someone to seat us. Overall, it's worth a visit!

quSBf5Qc1GERvwVDUGsRAw.text: I stumbled across Pizza Pilgrims late one Wednesday night, fresh from a few hours of rehearsals. I was hungry and tired, with a keen craving for a friendly place where I could have some real, fresh pizza. I had passed by Pizza Express (and given it the side eye- I really think their pizza is overrated), and had already checked out the scene at Homeslice (good pizza - but it was crowded and busy). I was on my way to my third option when I passed by this friendly place.Honestly, I think what made me turn around and walk back was... the smell. The herbal aroma of oregano and basil and the warm, comforting smell of fresh pizza dough baking in the oven - this was the smell I had been looking for. The restaurant had a very friendly air, quiet enough even with a few tables full, nicely spacious (with more seating downstairs) with classic pizzeria checkered tablecloths and figurines of New York icons on the wall, holding slices. It was late - around 10 or so, a half hour before closing - but the service was incredibly friendly and had me seated at the front counter in no time.  I went with a simple Margherita with added fennel sausage (couldn't resist), and a glass of their house white wine. The wine was surprisingly nice - aromatic and fruity but still nicely dry - and the pizza was delicious. Thick, chewy crust, big chunks of mozzarella, and dots of savory sausage. I added some chili flakes and then dug in. Don't get me wrong - it wasn't the world's best pizza!! I will agree it was pretty soggy/thin in the middle of the pie, but honestly it didn't bother me. The flavors were good, the ambience was friendly, and the service very agreeable. All in all, it was exactly what I had been craving. And I had the leftovers for breakfast this morning!

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Margherita pizza with added fennel sausage, and a glass of the house white wine. Seated at the front counter.

0TfGydknm-w3Nn8O-RINhA.text: Pretty good pizza! I ordered the salami pizza and it had a good flavor. It could've used a lot more basil, but other than that it was pretty good. The staff was friendly and helpful and the pizza was done in about 7 minutes! The pizza is also affordable at just 9 pounds for the salami and even cheaper for other pizza flavors.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom

IOvha97a6ujhJeRWkWUKyQ.text: First night in London and we stumbled across this quaint little pizza place after walking around the shops at Liberty. We ordered two - a Filetti and a traditional Margherita (personally preferred the Marg hence the lack of photo as I tucked straight into it) and the crusts were probably one of the top five best I've ever had in my life. Along with the great chewy, soft crust the pizza itself had nice tangy tomato sauce, soggy center, milky mozzarella - all the qualities one would come to expect in a great Naples style pizza. No slices so be prepared to use your fork/knife skills (fellow Americans, I'm talking to you) which is how Neapolitan styled pizzas should be eaten anyways. I'm seeing a lot of comparison to this and NY style pizza. How is there even a comparison? It's apples and oranges, folks.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Filetti pizza. Excellent crust!

kwMb5fXiX64xWmZgt5KIqA.text: This is one of the quieter PP locations, due to the never ending Crossrail/Lizzie Line project going on at Tott Ct Rd. I do like the staff here and their cute arty touches (like the super-fat TMNT who blames pizza for ruining his life!)The pizza is a little soft-based for my taste but there are lots of interesting toppings and they were accommodating when I asked for mozarella-less pizza (I find it too chewy here!)So, yes, do support this fun and flirty chain. And wear layers you can remove - it gets steamy downstairs!

iDHlVtgU2Yp9xfwACRYo0g.text: I really wanted to like this place, the vibe and great but the pizza feel flat - a little soggy and the cheese didn't taste good - no from me!It is a very popular place with seating on the lower level and gets crowded

C2NOhFv2Ze3ryo-oJc5tCg.text: Ive eaten here a few times now and it has become my go to for a pizza whilst out around the area. Every so often it will have interesting 'guest' pizzas, but on the whole the menu is focused on a few great simple, tried and tested greats. My personal favourite is the Gorgonzola pizza. The 4 star rating is purely down to personal preference (I would prefer a slightly crispier base). All in all, it's always very solid Pizza.In terms of staff, they always appear happy and friendly and I've always had a pleasant experience.

--JDra0qA6JNOO8kbnDdcg.text: As a self-confessed pizza enthusiast, the fact I still hadn't given Pizza Pilgrims a try until recently was a slightly baffling circumstance. There are now five branches across the city, as well as the company's very own street food van that takes their pizza out and about around town. Pizza Pilgrims' menu is pretty simple - something I'm totally down with as the girl who once had a teary breakdown in Sainsburys over what yoghurts to buy. I had the Salsicca e Friarelli pizza - topped with fennel sausage, chilli, wild broccoli, parmesan and olive oil. AND IT WAS DELICIOUS. Plenty of topping, the sausage and broccoli worked really well together.The pizza dough is also something pretty special - normally, I'm not big on crusts, preferring to eat as much topping as possible before I'm full. But I absolutely scoffed the crusts on these without a second thought.The selection of craft beers and lager is small yet well-thought out - I went for a can of the Birra Moretti, which was light, easy to drink and worked really well with the pizza. If you're feeling a bit more fancy, there's also a small range of cocktails to choose from - I loved the sound of Lola's Cherry Cola - Disaronno, Prosecco and Chinotto topped with a glacé cherry. And for £6, it's a relatively inexpensive Soho restaurant cocktail too.We grabbed a bowl of mixed olives for sharing - a good sized portion to whet our appetites before the dough-y goodness that was about to hit our table. I also loved the sound of the Buffalo mozzarella with smoked tomatoes, black pepper and rocket.With none of the regular pizzas on the menu going over a tenner, and starting at just £5.50 for a Marinara, Pizza Pilgrims definitely offers an affordable pizza experience if you're in penny-pinching-pre-payday mode. In fact, there's probably enough in my change box to afford one RIGHT now. Seeya in a bit, guys.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Pizza Pilgrims, Soho
Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Beer @ Pizza Pilgrims, Soho
Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Olives @ Pizza Pilgrims, Soho

XJrBEL4WtkTe9jUkxjuYfw.text: So I've been wanting to come to this place for a very long time and I am extremely glad I did! Situated towards the Oxford Street end of Dean Street, this particular branch has the air of a traditional, old school, Italian restaurant. The main kitchen with the wood fired oven is at the top and the restaurant area and bar downstairs. The walls are adorned with famous movie posters but in Italian, not in English. We got there quite early and were given our pick of tables. I ordered the Salsiccia E Friarielli, which is a white pizza with fresh fennel sausage, chilli, wild broccoli, parmesan, basil and olive oil, whilst my companion ordered the Ndjua which is a Margherita with ndjua, a spicy Calabrian pork sausage. We decided to split the pizzas in half which was such a good idea as BOTH pizzas were delicious. The dough was soft, the base was thin, there was a sufficient amount of cheese on both pizzas and they were both flavoured exquisitely! LOVED it!For dessert we ordered the Nutella & salted ricotta pizza ring to share. It was yummy but I was soooooo full that I don't think I appreciated it as much as I should have! The drink I ordered was pretty tasty too - Lola's Cherry Cola - Disaronno, Prosecco, Chinotto and a glace cherry! Extremely delicious and totally moreish!The reason why this place gets 4 stars is because the toilets were a bit grim and the service was a bit slow. We were waiting for nearly half an hour for the waiter to clean our plates away. Admittedly, I had crusts on mine but I hadn't touched them for a while. He even came to our table, replenished our tap water and did not touch our plates. Some people might think I am being picky so I apologise and definitely do not let that put you off!

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Nduja pizza
Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Lola's cherry cola
Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Salsicca e Friarielli

WAttAwxpaVpS2JQnXYb-Kw.text: We've been at Pilgrims Pizza a few times (mostly in this branch, the first one in London) and it's always perfection! Pizzas are amazing, with fresh and great products, perfectly cooked, tasty, simple. This is quite the best pizza in London in my opinion ! The service is pretty nice too, smiling, efficient and generous with explanations :-) It really tastes like Italy ! The atmosphere is also pretty nice, the choice of music was great (some oldies but it was perfect :)). We had a great time and ended the meals with some desserts : I tried the vanilla ice cream with sea salt and olive oil. It was interesting but to be honest, not my favourite dessert :p My friends chose the nutella and ricotta pizza ring (following the waitress'advice) and this one was really convincing :-) We definitely love this place and we'll be back.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Dessert with Nutella and ricotta

0rtw_kBsdKuxPiFk4XMaPQ.text: Honestly...Your pizza is supposed to be a soft crust yes, understood. but when the middle is cut into and it's undercooked, and the cheese is mostly water because the mozzarella was not tended to properly and it leaks a milky floury white...you have problems that need sorting. If your competitor/doppelganger Franco Manca is using the same model, it would be something to be of concern when you're messing about in this way.

rLa-Az1dBYMXaLXE5s-Ayw.text: Didn't serve us two nights in a row. We went there after watching plays in the area. First night it was right around 10:30pm which is when they close which is understandable. Next night we got there at 10:15pm (on a Saturday) and somehow they were closing early.

LtqouhfCt42j6c3eJFseFg.text: I've wanted to try Pizza Pilgrims for aaaaages but just never end up choosing pizza if I'm going out for dinner.My bf and I had just finished a round of crazy golf at Swingers and were starving! The two pop ups Swingers had in the venue for that month were The Bowler or Pizza Pilgrims (resident)Now I also really wanted to try the bowler however pizza or meatballs wins for me so my bf and I both shared a pizza!The choice was of only two unlike the soho restaurantsWe went for the nduja sausage one and myyyy was it good! Dough good sauce good cheese good sausage good! Yum! I hear they do takeaway so will pick this over dominoes any day!

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom

cPHSieeHLmn9cOBCEf0BFw.text: This is some great pizza! I'm literally writing this after my last bite of a margarita with sausage. The crust is so soft and gooey, everything had a super fresh taste and was so flavourful. Great customer service too!

P_rvcyMOjZCunJ8_HAlk3g.text: Five star pizza place here!  Wow... Where do I start?   The pizza makers are straight outta Italy.  Bonus!  Our pizzas were all amazing.  I'm stepping out on a limb and going to say top three of my life.  I've eaten a ton of pizza in my day so that's definitely saying something.  Definitely go here if you are in London.  You won't be disappointing.  Sad thing is it will ruin pizza for you if you don't live near this place.  Just go there.  You will see.

photos.caption: Photo of Pizza Pilgrims - London, United Kingdom. Marg Pizza w/ Calabrian pork and fresh mozz.....

N9JVapEBB6I5m6TesxMMzA.text: This place is the closest thing you will find to a real Italian pizza restaurant. They have a wide variety of pizzas, all of them home made with really good quality ingredients. The crust is really crispy and tasty and not too doughy unlike other places I've been. They also have a good selection of wines and local beers like Brixton (one of my favourites). Haven't had the chance to try the desserts but they looked really good and well presented.You can have a really nice lunch or dinner for around £10 or £12 which is way cheaper than any other place I've been. The staff is quite friendly and the atmosphere is great. The decoration is really unique and they even have a computer with game emulators shaped like the old 80s-90s arcade coin machines!
